ğŸš€ Concurrency Battle: Java 21 Virtual Threads vs. Go GoroutinesConcurrency plays a crucial role in performance and scalability â€” and the way programming languages handle threads can make all the difference. Today, weâ€™re comparing two powerful approaches: Java 21â€™s Virtual Threads and Goâ€™s Goroutines.â˜• Java 21: The Rise of Virtual ThreadsJava 21 introduces Virtual Threads, a major step forward in simplifying concurrent programming.ğŸ”¹ Traditional Threading: Previously, Java required careful synchronization with synchronized blocks, ReentrantLock, and thread-safe collections like ConcurrentHashMap, leading to complex and error-prone code.ğŸ”¹ Virtual Threads: The JVM manages these lightweight threads, allowing developers to write straightforward, blocking-style code without worrying about the performance penalties of OS threads. In many cases, they dramatically reduce the need for explicit synchronization.ğŸ¿ Go: Built for ConcurrencyGo was designed with concurrency at its core. Its lightweight Goroutines and channel-based communication model make concurrent programming clean and powerful.ğŸ”¹ Goroutines: Cheap to spawn and managed by the Go runtime scheduler, they enable massive concurrency with minimal overhead.ğŸ”¹ Channels: Goâ€™s idiomatic way to coordinate goroutines â€” allowing communication to replace shared memory and locks in most cases.ğŸ— Key Differencesâ€¢ Synchronization: Java uses thread-safe constructs; Go favors communication via channels. â€¢ Complexity: Go is simpler out of the box. Java has improved significantly with Virtual Threads. â€¢ Runtime Management: Both models are managed by their respective runtimes, enabling lightweight concurrency. â€¢ Maturity: Goâ€™s model is well-established. Javaâ€™s Virtual Threads are newer but promising.âœ… In ConclusionJava 21â€™s Virtual Threads are a big leap, offering a concurrency model closer to Goâ€™s simplicity. While Go remains a go-to for clean concurrent code, Java developers now have modern tools to write scalable, readable, and efficient concurrent applications.ğŸ’¬ How have Virtual Threads or Goroutines shaped your projects? ğŸš€ Concurrency Battle: Java 21 Virtual Threads vs. Go GoroutinesConcurrency plays a crucial role in performance and scalability â€” and the way programming languages handle threads can make all the difference. Today, weâ€™re comparing two powerful approaches: Java 21â€™s Virtual Threads and Goâ€™s Goroutines.â˜• Java 21: The Rise of Virtual ThreadsJava 21 introduces Virtual Threads, a major step forward in simplifying concurrent programming.ğŸ”¹ Traditional Threading: Previously, Java required careful synchronization with synchronized blocks, ReentrantLock, and thread-safe collections like ConcurrentHashMap, leading to complex and error-prone code.ğŸ”¹ Virtual Threads: The JVM manages these lightweight threads, allowing developers to write straightforward, blocking-style code without worrying about the performance penalties of OS threads. In many cases, they dramatically reduce the need for explicit synchronization.ğŸ¿ Go: Built for ConcurrencyGo was designed with concurrency at its core. Its lightweight Goroutines and channel-based communication model make concurrent programming clean and powerful.ğŸ”¹ Goroutines: Cheap to spawn and managed by the Go runtime scheduler, they enable massive concurrency with minimal overhead.ğŸ”¹ Channels: Goâ€™s idiomatic way to coordinate goroutines â€” allowing communication to replace shared memory and locks in most cases.ğŸ— Key Differencesâ€¢ Synchronization: Java uses thread-safe constructs; Go favors communication via channels. â€¢ Complexity: Go is simpler out of the box. Java has improved significantly with Virtual Threads. â€¢ Runtime Management: Both models are managed by their respective runtimes, enabling lightweight concurrency. â€¢ Maturity: Goâ€™s model is well-established. Javaâ€™s Virtual Threads are newer but promising.âœ… In ConclusionJava 21â€™s Virtual Threads are a big leap, offering a concurrency model closer to Goâ€™s simplicity. While Go remains a go-to for clean concurrent code, Java developers now have modern tools to write scalable, readable, and efficient concurrent applications.ğŸ’¬ How have Virtual Threads or Goroutines shaped your projects? Letâ€™s discuss!hashtag#Java21 hashtag#Go hashtag#Concurrency hashtag#VirtualThreads hashtag#Goroutines hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#Threading

DAO Labs ILO Experience: Journey to a Contributively Just EcosystemIn the Web3 world, the number of fair systems where contributions are recognized is limited. However, the ILO (Initial Labor Offering) model developed by DAO Labs is set to change this perception forever. With both transparency and labor-based rewards, this model is not only a token distribution tool, but also a building block for sustainable community building. In this article, I will shed light on DAO Labs' ILO model with my personal experience.ğŸ“Œ Introduction to the Pledge PoolMy involvement as a social miner in DAO Labs' projects played an important role in my selection to the Autonomys Network ILO process. My interaction with the community, the quality of my content production and my previous contributions led to my inclusion in the Pledge Pool. Being included in this pool means that the amount of token allocation you receive will be directly determined by your work output. The higher the quality of the content you produce, the more reward you will receive. This system offers a fair distribution process based on labor and value, beyond traditional airdrops.ğŸ“Œ ILO PhaseBetween March 24 and April 24, 2025, completing tasks spread over four weeks allowed me to get to know Autonomys Network better. Each week, I created content and talked about the project on X (Twitter), Reddit and blogs. By sharing this content with my followers, I made not only the project but also my own experience visible. Sharing a link to a sample piece of content and posting screenshots of the task submission pages on the platform gave the community a genuine and trustworthy impression. The fact that my two-week progress attracted attention in the community motivated me even more.ğŸ“Œ Flexible Vesting and Autonomys HubThe Flexible Vesting model offered by Autonomys Hub has shaped my motivation based on long-term contributions rather than short-term. Some of the tokens I earned were released immediately, while the rest were planned to be released over time. In the process, I not only completed my own tasks, but also contributed to the sustainable growth of the community by mentoring new social miners. Staying active in the vesting process allowed me to take ownership of the project and develop a professional perspective.

ğŸš€ Concurrency Battle: Java 21 Virtual Threads vs. Go GoroutinesConcurrency plays a crucial role in performance and scalability â€” and the way programming languages handle threads can make all the difference. Today, weâ€™re comparing two powerful approaches: Java 21â€™s Virtual Threads and Goâ€™s Goroutines.â˜• Java 21: The Rise of Virtual ThreadsJava 21 introduces Virtual Threads, a major step forward in simplifying concurrent programming.ğŸ”¹ Traditional Threading: Previously, Java required careful synchronization with synchronized blocks, ReentrantLock, and thread-safe collections like ConcurrentHashMap, leading to complex and error-prone code.ğŸ”¹ Virtual Threads: The JVM manages these lightweight threads, allowing developers to write straightforward, blocking-style code without worrying about the performance penalties of OS threads. In many cases, they dramatically reduce the need for explicit synchronization.ğŸ¿ Go: Built for ConcurrencyGo was designed with concurrency at its core. Its lightweight Goroutines and channel-based communication model make concurrent programming clean and powerful.ğŸ”¹ Goroutines: Cheap to spawn and managed by the Go runtime scheduler, they enable massive concurrency with minimal overhead.ğŸ”¹ Channels: Goâ€™s idiomatic way to coordinate goroutines â€” allowing communication to replace shared memory and locks in most cases.ğŸ— Key Differencesâ€¢ Synchronization: Java uses thread-safe constructs; Go favors communication via channels. â€¢ Complexity: Go is simpler out of the box. Java has improved significantly with Virtual Threads. â€¢ Runtime Management: Both models are managed by their respective runtimes, enabling lightweight concurrency. â€¢ Maturity: Goâ€™s model is well-established. Javaâ€™s Virtual Threads are newer but promising.âœ… In ConclusionJava 21â€™s Virtual Threads are a big leap, offering a concurrency model closer to Goâ€™s simplicity. While Go remains a go-to for clean concurrent code, Java developers now have modern tools to write scalable, readable, and efficient concurrent applications.ğŸ’¬ How have Virtual Threads or Goroutines shaped your projects? Letâ€™s discuss!hashtag#Java21 hashtag#Go hashtag#Concurrency hashtag#VirtualThreads hashtag#Goroutines hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#Threading

ğŸš€ Concurrency Battle: Java 21 Virtual Threads vs. Go GoroutinesConcurrency plays a crucial role in performance and scalability â€” and the way programming languages handle threads can make all the difference. Today, weâ€™re comparing two powerful approaches: Java 21â€™s Virtual Threads and Goâ€™s Goroutines.â˜• Java 21: The Rise of Virtual ThreadsJava 21 introduces Virtual Threads, a major step forward in simplifying concurrent programming.ğŸ”¹ Traditional Threading: Previously, Java required careful synchronization with synchronized blocks, ReentrantLock, and thread-safe collections like ConcurrentHashMap, leading to complex and error-prone code.ğŸ”¹ Virtual Threads: The JVM manages these lightweight threads, allowing developers to write straightforward, blocking-style code without worrying about the performance penalties of OS threads. In many cases, they dramatically reduce the need for explicit synchronization.ğŸ¿ Go: Built for ConcurrencyGo was designed with concurrency at its core. Its lightweight Goroutines and channel-based communication model make concurrent programming clean and powerful.ğŸ”¹ Goroutines: Cheap to spawn and managed by the Go runtime scheduler, they enable massive concurrency with minimal overhead.ğŸ”¹ Channels: Goâ€™s idiomatic way to coordinate goroutines â€” allowing communication to replace shared memory and locks in most cases.ğŸ— Key Differencesâ€¢ Synchronization: Java uses thread-safe constructs; Go favors communication via channels. â€¢ Complexity: Go is simpler out of the box. Java has improved significantly with Virtual Threads. â€¢ Runtime Management: Both models are managed by their respective runtimes, enabling lightweight concurrency. â€¢ Maturity: Goâ€™s model is well-established. Javaâ€™s Virtual Threads are newer but promising.âœ… In ConclusionJava 21â€™s Virtual Threads are a big leap, offering a concurrency model closer to Goâ€™s simplicity. While Go remains a go-to for clean concurrent code, Java developers now have modern tools to write scalable, readable, and efficient concurrent applications.ğŸ’¬ How have Virtual Threads or Goroutines shaped your projects? Letâ€™s discuss!hashtag#Java21 hashtag#Go hashtag#Concurrency hashtag#VirtualThreads hashtag#Goroutines hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#Threading

DAO Labs ILO Experience: Journey to a Contributively Just EcosystemIn the Web3 world, the number of fair systems where contributions are recognized is limited. However, the ILO (Initial Labor Offering) model developed by DAO Labs is set to change this perception forever. With both transparency and labor-based rewards, this model is not only a token distribution tool, but also a building block for sustainable community building. In this article, I will shed light on DAO Labs' ILO model with my personal experience.ğŸ“Œ Introduction to the Pledge PoolMy involvement as a social miner in DAO Labs' projects played an important role in my selection to the Autonomys Network ILO process. My interaction with the community, the quality of my content production and my previous contributions led to my inclusion in the Pledge Pool. Being included in this pool means that the amount of token allocation you receive will be directly determined by your work output. The higher the quality of the content you produce, the more reward you will receive. This system offers a fair distribution process based on labor and value, beyond traditional airdrops.ğŸ“Œ ILO PhaseBetween March 24 and April 24, 2025, completing tasks spread over four weeks allowed me to get to know Autonomys Network better. Each week, I created content and talked about the project on X (Twitter), Reddit and blogs. By sharing this content with my followers, I made not only the project but also my own experience visible. Sharing a link to a sample piece of content and posting screenshots of the task submission pages on the platform gave the community a genuine and trustworthy impression. The fact that my two-week progress attracted attention in the community motivated me even more.ğŸ“Œ Flexible Vesting and Autonomys HubThe Flexible Vesting model offered by Autonomys Hub has shaped my motivation based on long-term contributions rather than short-term. Some of the tokens I earned were released immediately, while the rest were planned to be released over time. In the process, I not only completed my own tasks, but also contributed to the sustainable growth of the community by mentoring new social miners. Staying active in the vesting process allowed me to take ownership of the project and develop a professional perspective.

I'm glad to point you at a HUGE new release of BRINGUP-BENCH, a benchmark suite for CPU and accelerator development. This new release includes 20 MORE BENCHMARKS, plus significant improvements that now allow Bringup-Bench to run WITHOUT any I/O DEVICES, RUNTIME LIBRARIES, or OPERATING SYSTEMS. You can check out the new release here: https://lnkd.in/gfW889FsHere is what is in the new release (version 1.6):* 20 new benchmarks added, now for a total of 85 benchmarks!* TARGETs can now exclude benchmarks from their tests by adding them to TARGET_EXCLUDES in the Makefile* more benchmarks are now working on more targets* the SPIKE reference target now supports 8 MB memory* HASHALONE targets now are self-checking* the QSORT library implementation is now much more robust* an FP libmin_printf() problem was fixed, and it affected some benchmark outputs (which have been corrected)* the SPIKE and SIMPLE targets are now completely separatedâ€‹What is Bringup-bench? The Bringup-bench benchmark suite is a collection of 85 standalone C benchmarks designed to assist in the initial testing and validation of CPUs and accelerators. The suite is built to be easily hosted on simulated or real CPU platforms with no I/O devices, runtime libraries, or operating systems.â€‹ Running Bringup-bench, it is possible to perform deep functional testing of your design and early performance analysis. The benchmarks have modest runtimes; for example, running Bringup-bench on the IBEX RISC-V CPU RTL with Verilator, the entire benchmark suite completes execution in under 30 minutes.If you have found these benchmarks useful, please share your experience in the comments below. I see a lot of activity on the repo, so I would love to learn more about how Bringup-bench is being used.hashtag#computerarchitecture hashtag#hardware hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#CPU hashtag#RISCV hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#verification hashtag#validation

ğŸš€ Concurrency Battle: Java 21 Virtual Threads vs. Go GoroutinesConcurrency plays a crucial role in performance and scalability â€” and the way programming languages handle threads can make all the difference. Today, weâ€™re comparing two powerful approaches: Java 21â€™s Virtual Threads and Goâ€™s Goroutines.â˜• Java 21: The Rise of Virtual ThreadsJava 21 introduces Virtual Threads, a major step forward in simplifying concurrent programming.ğŸ”¹ Traditional Threading: Previously, Java required careful synchronization with synchronized blocks, ReentrantLock, and thread-safe collections like ConcurrentHashMap, leading to complex and error-prone code.ğŸ”¹ Virtual Threads: The JVM manages these lightweight threads, allowing developers to write straightforward, blocking-style code without worrying about the performance penalties of OS threads. In many cases, they dramatically reduce the need for explicit synchronization.ğŸ¿ Go: Built for ConcurrencyGo was designed with concurrency at its core. Its lightweight Goroutines and channel-based communication model make concurrent programming clean and powerful.ğŸ”¹ Goroutines: Cheap to spawn and managed by the Go runtime scheduler, they enable massive concurrency with minimal overhead.ğŸ”¹ Channels: Goâ€™s idiomatic way to coordinate goroutines â€” allowing communication to replace shared memory and locks in most cases.ğŸ— Key Differencesâ€¢ Synchronization: Java uses thread-safe constructs; Go favors communication via channels. â€¢ Complexity: Go is simpler out of the box. Java has improved significantly with Virtual Threads. â€¢ Runtime Management: Both models are managed by their respective runtimes, enabling lightweight concurrency. â€¢ Maturity: Goâ€™s model is well-established. Javaâ€™s Virtual Threads are newer but promising.âœ… In ConclusionJava 21â€™s Virtual Threads are a big leap, offering a concurrency model closer to Goâ€™s simplicity. While Go remains a go-to for clean concurrent code, Java developers now have modern tools to write scalable, readable, and efficient concurrent applications.ğŸ’¬ How have Virtual Threads or Goroutines shaped your projects? Letâ€™s discuss!hashtag#Java21 hashtag#Go hashtag#Concurrency hashtag#VirtualThreads hashtag#Goroutines hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#Threading

DAO Labs ILO Experience: Journey to a Contributively Just EcosystemIn the Web3 world, the number of fair systems where contributions are recognized is limited. However, the ILO (Initial Labor Offering) model developed by DAO Labs is set to change this perception forever. With both transparency and labor-based rewards, this model is not only a token distribution tool, but also a building block for sustainable community building. In this article, I will shed light on DAO Labs' ILO model with my personal experience.ğŸ“Œ Introduction to the Pledge PoolMy involvement as a social miner in DAO Labs' projects played an important role in my selection to the Autonomys Network ILO process. My interaction with the community, the quality of my content production and my previous contributions led to my inclusion in the Pledge Pool. Being included in this pool means that the amount of token allocation you receive will be directly determined by your work output. The higher the quality of the content you produce, the more reward you will receive. This system offers a fair distribution process based on labor and value, beyond traditional airdrops.ğŸ“Œ ILO PhaseBetween March 24 and April 24, 2025, completing tasks spread over four weeks allowed me to get to know Autonomys Network better. Each week, I created content and talked about the project on X (Twitter), Reddit and blogs. By sharing this content with my followers, I made not only the project but also my own experience visible. I'm glad to point you at a HUGE new release of BRINGUP-BENCH, a benchmark suite for CPU and accelerator development. This new release includes 20 MORE BENCHMARKS, plus significant improvements that now allow Bringup-Bench to run WITHOUT any I/O DEVICES, RUNTIME LIBRARIES, or OPERATING SYSTEMS. You can check out the new release here: https://lnkd.in/gfW889FsHere is what is in the new release (version 1.6):* 20 new benchmarks added, now for a total of 85 benchmarks!* TARGETs can now exclude benchmarks from their tests by adding them to TARGET_EXCLUDES in the Makefile* more benchmarks are now working on more targets* the SPIKE reference target now supports 8 MB memory* HASHALONE targets now are self-checking* the QSORT library implementation is now much more robust* an FP libmin_printf() problem was fixed, and it affected some benchmark outputs (which have been corrected)* the SPIKE and SIMPLE targets are now completely separatedâ€‹What is Bringup-bench? The Bringup-bench benchmark suite is a collection of 85 standalone C benchmarks designed to assist in the initial testing and validation of CPUs and accelerators. The suite is built to be easily hosted on simulated or real CPU platforms with no I/O devices, runtime libraries, or operating systems.â€‹ Running Bringup-bench, it is possible to perform deep functional testing of your design and early performance analysis. The benchmarks have modest runtimes; for example, running Bringup-bench on the IBEX RISC-V CPU RTL with Verilator, the entire benchmark suite completes execution in under 30 minutes.If you have found these benchmarks useful, please share your experience in the comments below. I see a lot of activity on the repo, so I would love to learn more about how Bringup-bench is being used.hashtag#computerarchitecture hashtag#hardware hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#CPU hashtag#RISCV hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#verification hashtag#validation

ğŸš€ Concurrency Battle: Java 21 Virtual Threads vs. Go GoroutinesConcurrency plays a crucial role in performance and scalability â€” and the way programming languages handle threads can make all the difference. Today, weâ€™re comparing two powerful approaches: Java 21â€™s Virtual Threads and Goâ€™s Goroutines.â˜• Java 21: The Rise of Virtual ThreadsJava 21 introduces Virtual Threads, a major step forward in simplifying concurrent programming.ğŸ”¹ Traditional Threading: Previously, Java required careful synchronization with synchronized blocks, ReentrantLock, and thread-safe collections like ConcurrentHashMap, leading to complex and error-prone code.ğŸ”¹ Virtual Threads: The JVM manages these lightweight threads, allowing developers to write straightforward, blocking-style code without worrying about the performance penalties of OS threads. In many cases, they dramatically reduce the need for explicit synchronization.ğŸ¿ Go: Built for ConcurrencyGo was designed with concurrency at its core. Its lightweight Goroutines and channel-based communication model make concurrent programming clean and powerful.ğŸ”¹ Goroutines: Cheap to spawn and managed by the Go runtime scheduler, they enable massive concurrency with minimal overhead.ğŸ”¹ Channels: Goâ€™s idiomatic way to coordinate goroutines â€” allowing communication to replace shared memory and locks in most cases.ğŸ— Key Differencesâ€¢ Synchronization: Java uses thread-safe constructs; Go favors communication via channels. â€¢ Complexity: Go is simpler out of the box. Java has improved significantly with Virtual Threads. â€¢ Runtime Management: Both models are managed by their respective runtimes, enabling lightweight concurrency. â€¢ Maturity: Goâ€™s model is well-established. Javaâ€™s Virtual Threads are newer but promising.âœ… In ConclusionJava 21â€™s Virtual Threads are a big leap, offering a concurrency model closer to Goâ€™s simplicity. While Go remains a go-to for clean concurrent code, Java developers now have modern tools to write scalable, readable, and efficient concurrent applications.ğŸ’¬ How have Virtual Threads or Goroutines shaped your projects? Letâ€™s discuss!hashtag#Java21 hashtag#Go hashtag#Concurrency hashtag#VirtualThreads hashtag#Goroutines hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#Threading

DAO Labs ILO Experience: Journey to a Contributively Just EcosystemIn the Web3 world, the number of fair systems where contributions are recognized is limited. However, the ILO (Initial Labor Offering) model developed by DAO Labs is set to change this perception forever. With both transparency and labor-based rewards, this model is not only a token distribution tool, but also a building block for sustainable community building. In this article, I will shed light on DAO Labs' ILO model with my personal experience.ğŸ“Œ Introduction to the Pledge PoolMy involvement as a social miner in DAO Labs' projects played an important role in my selection to the Autonomys Network ILO process. My interaction with the community, the quality of my content production and my previous contributions led to my inclusion in the Pledge Pool. Being included in this pool means that the amount of token allocation you receive will be directly determined by your work output. The higher the quality of the content you produce, the more reward you will receive. This system offers a fair distribution process based on labor and value, beyond traditional airdrops.ğŸ“Œ ILO PhaseBetween March 24 and April 24, 2025, completing tasks spread over four weeks allowed me to get to know Autonomys Network better. Each week, I created content and talked about the project on X (Twitter), Reddit and blogs. By sharing this content with my followers, I made not only the project but also my own experience visible. Sharing a link to a sample piece of content and posting screenshots of the task submission pages on the platform gave the community a genuine and trustworthy impression. The fact that my two-week progress attracted attention in the community motivated me even more.ğŸ“Œ Flexible Vesting and Autonomys HubThe Flexible Vesting model offered by Autonomys Hub has shaped my motivation based on long-term contributions rather than short-term. Some of the tokens I earned were released immediately, while the rest were planned to be released over time. In the process, I not only completed my own tasks, but also contributed to the sustainable growth of the community by mentoring new social miners. Staying active in the vesting process allowed me to take ownership of the project and develop a professional perspective.

I'm glad to point you at a HUGE new release of BRINGUP-BENCH, a benchmark suite for CPU and accelerator development. This new release includes 20 MORE BENCHMARKS, plus significant improvements that now allow Bringup-Bench to run WITHOUT any I/O DEVICES, RUNTIME LIBRARIES, or OPERATING SYSTEMS. You can check out the new release here: https://lnkd.in/gfW889FsHere is what is in the new release (version 1.6):* 20 new benchmarks added, now for a total of 85 benchmarks!* TARGETs can now exclude benchmarks from their tests by adding them to TARGET_EXCLUDES in the Makefile* more benchmarks are now working on more targets* the SPIKE reference target now supports 8 MB memory* HASHALONE targets now are self-checking* the QSORT library implementation is now much more robust* an FP libmin_printf() problem was fixed, and it affected some benchmark outputs (which have been corrected)* the SPIKE and SIMPLE targets are now completely separatedâ€‹What is Bringup-bench? The Bringup-bench benchmark suite is a collection of 85 standalone C benchmarks designed to assist in the initial testing and validation of CPUs and accelerators. The suite is built to be easily hosted on simulated or real CPU platforms with no I/O devices, runtime libraries, or operating systems.â€‹ Running Bringup-bench, it is possible to perform deep functional testing of your design and early performance analysis. The benchmarks have modest runtimes; for example, running Bringup-bench on the IBEX RISC-V CPU RTL with Verilator, the entire benchmark suite completes execution in under 30 minutes.If you have found these benchmarks useful, please share your experience in the comments below. I see a lot of activity on the repo, so I would love to learn more about how Bringup-bench is being used.hashtag#computerarchitecture hashtag#hardware hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#CPU hashtag#RISCV hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#verification hashtag#validation

ğŸš€ Concurrency Battle: Java 21 Virtual Threads vs. Go GoroutinesConcurrency plays a crucial role in performance and scalability â€” and the way programming languages handle threads can make all the difference. Today, weâ€™re comparing two powerful approaches: Java 21â€™s Virtual Threads and Goâ€™s Goroutines.â˜• Java 21: The Rise of Virtual ThreadsJava 21 introduces Virtual Threads, a major step forward in simplifying concurrent programming.ğŸ”¹ Traditional Threading: Previously, Java required careful synchronization with synchronized blocks, ReentrantLock, and thread-safe collections like ConcurrentHashMap, leading to complex and error-prone code.ğŸ”¹ Virtual Threads: The JVM manages these lightweight threads, allowing developers to write straightforward, blocking-style code without worrying about the performance penalties of OS threads. In many cases, they dramatically reduce the need for explicit synchronization.ğŸ¿ Go: Built for ConcurrencyGo was designed with concurrency at its core. Its lightweight Goroutines and channel-based communication model make concurrent programming clean and powerful.ğŸ”¹ Goroutines: Cheap to spawn and managed by the Go runtime scheduler, they enable massive concurrency with minimal overhead.ğŸ”¹ Channels: Goâ€™s idiomatic way to coordinate goroutines â€” allowing communication to replace shared memory and locks in most cases.ğŸ— Key Differencesâ€¢ Synchronization: Java uses thread-safe constructs; Go favors communication via channels. â€¢ Complexity: Go is simpler out of the box. Java has improved significantly with Virtual Threads. â€¢ Runtime Management: Both models are managed by their respective runtimes, enabling lightweight concurrency. â€¢ Maturity: Goâ€™s model is well-established. Javaâ€™s Virtual Threads are newer but promising.âœ… In ConclusionJava 21â€™s Virtual Threads are a big leap, offering a concurrency model closer to Goâ€™s simplicity. While Go remains a go-to for clean concurrent code, Java developers now have modern tools to write scalable, readable, and efficient concurrent applications.ğŸ’¬ How have Virtual Threads or Goroutines shaped your projects? Letâ€™s discuss!hashtag#Java21 hashtag#Go hashtag#Concurrency hashtag#VirtualThreads hashtag#Goroutines hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#Threading

DAO Labs ILO Experience: Journey to a Contributively Just EcosystemIn the Web3 world, the number of fair systems where contributions are recognized is limited. However, the ILO (Initial Labor Offering) model developed by DAO Labs is set to change this perception forever. With both transparency and labor-based rewards, this model is not only a token distribution tool, but also a building block for sustainable community building. In this article, I will shed light on DAO Labs' ILO model with my personal experience.ğŸ“Œ Introduction to the Pledge PoolMy involvement as a social miner in DAO Labs' projects played an important role in my selection to the Autonomys Network ILO process. My interaction with the community, the quality of my content production and my previous contributions led to my inclusion in the Pledge Pool. Being included in this pool means that the amount of token allocation you receive will be directly determined by your work output. The higher the quality of the content you produce, the more reward you will receive. This system offers a fair distribution process based on labor and value, beyond traditional airdrops.ğŸ“Œ ILO PhaseBetween March 24 and April 24, 2025, completing tasks spread over four weeks allowed me to get to know Autonomys Network better. Each week, I created content and talked about the project on X (Twitter), Reddit and blogs. By sharing this content with my followers, I made not only the project but also my own experience visible. Sharing a link to a sample piece of content and posting screenshots of the task submission pages on the platform gave the community a genuine and trustworthy impression. The fact that my two-week progress attracted attention in the community motivated me even more.ğŸ“Œ Flexible Vesting and Autonomys HubThe Flexible Vesting model offered by Autonomys Hub has shaped my motivation based on long-term contributions rather than short-term. Some of the tokens I earned were released immediately, while the rest were planned to be released over time. In the process, I not only completed my own tasks, but also contributed to the sustainable growth of the community by mentoring new social miners. Staying active in the vesting process allowed me to take ownership of the project and develop a professional perspective.

I'm glad to point you at a HUGE new release of BRINGUP-BENCH, a benchmark suite for CPU and accelerator development. This new release includes 20 MORE BENCHMARKS, plus significant improvements that now allow Bringup-Bench to run WITHOUT any I/O DEVICES, RUNTIME LIBRARIES, or OPERATING SYSTEMS. You can check out the new release here: https://lnkd.in/gfW889FsHere is what is in the new release (version 1.6):* 20 new benchmarks added, now for a total of 85 benchmarks!* TARGETs can now exclude benchmarks from their tests by adding them to TARGET_EXCLUDES in the Makefile* more benchmarks are now working on more targets* the SPIKE reference target now supports 8 MB memory* HASHALONE targets now are self-checking* the QSORT library implementation is now much more robust* an FP libmin_printf() problem was fixed, and it affected some benchmark outputs (which have been corrected)* the SPIKE and SIMPLE targets are now completely separatedâ€‹What is Bringup-bench? The Bringup-bench benchmark suite is a collection of 85 standalone C benchmarks designed to assist in the initial testing and validation of CPUs and accelerators. The suite is built to be easily hosted on simulated or real CPU platforms with no I/O devices, runtime libraries, or operating systems.â€‹ Running Bringup-bench, it is possible to perform deep functional testing of your design and early performance analysis. The benchmarks have modest runtimes; for example, running Bringup-bench on the IBEX RISC-V CPU RTL with Verilator, the entire benchmark suite completes execution in under 30 minutes.If you have found these benchmarks useful, please share your experience in the comments below. I see a lot of activity on the repo, so I would love to learn more about how Bringup-bench is being used.hashtag#computerarchitecture hashtag#hardware hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#CPU hashtag#RISCV hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#verification hashtag#validation

ğŸš€ Concurrency Battle: Java 21 Virtual Threads vs. Go GoroutinesConcurrency plays a crucial role in performance and scalability â€” and the way programming languages handle threads can make all the difference. Today, weâ€™re comparing two powerful approaches: Java 21â€™s Virtual Threads and Goâ€™s Goroutines.â˜• Java 21: The Rise of Virtual ThreadsJava 21 introduces Virtual Threads, a major step forward in simplifying concurrent programming.ğŸ”¹ Traditional Threading: Previously, Java required careful synchronization with synchronized blocks, ReentrantLock, and thread-safe collections like ConcurrentHashMap, leading to complex and error-prone code.ğŸ”¹ Virtual Threads: The JVM manages these lightweight threads, allowing developers to write straightforward, blocking-style code without worrying about the performance penalties of OS threads. In many cases, they dramatically reduce the need for explicit synchronization.ğŸ¿ Go: Built for ConcurrencyGo was designed with concurrency at its core. Its lightweight Goroutines and channel-based communication model make concurrent programming clean and powerful.ğŸ”¹ Goroutines: Cheap to spawn and managed by the Go runtime scheduler, they enable massive concurrency with minimal overhead.ğŸ”¹ Channels: Goâ€™s idiomatic way to coordinate goroutines â€” allowing communication to replace shared memory and locks in most cases.ğŸ— Key Differencesâ€¢ Synchronization: Java uses thread-safe constructs; Go favors communication via channels. â€¢ Complexity: Go is simpler out of the box. Java has improved significantly with Virtual Threads. â€¢ Runtime Management: Both models are managed by their respective runtimes, enabling lightweight concurrency. â€¢ Maturity: Goâ€™s model is well-established. Javaâ€™s Virtual Threads are newer but promising.âœ… In ConclusionJava 21â€™s Virtual Threads are a big leap, offering a concurrency model closer to Goâ€™s simplicity. While Go remains a go-to for clean concurrent code, Java developers now have modern tools to write scalable, readable, and efficient concurrent applications.ğŸ’¬ How have Virtual Threads or Goroutines shaped your projects? Letâ€™s discuss!hashtag#Java21 hashtag#Go hashtag#Concurrency hashtag#VirtualThreads hashtag#Goroutines hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#Threading

DAO Labs ILO Experience: Journey to a Contributively Just EcosystemIn the Web3 world, the number of fair systems where contributions are recognized is limited. However, the ILO (Initial Labor Offering) model developed by DAO Labs is set to change this perception forever. With both transparency and labor-based rewards, this model is not only a token distribution tool, but also a building block for sustainable community building. In this article, I will shed light on DAO Labs' ILO model with my personal experience.ğŸ“Œ Introduction to the Pledge PoolMy involvement as a social miner in DAO Labs' projects played an important role in my selection to the Autonomys Network ILO process. My interaction with the community, the quality of my content production and my previous contributions led to my inclusion in the Pledge Pool. Being included in this pool means that the amount of token allocation you receive will be directly determined by your work output. The higher the quality of the content you produce, the more reward you will receive. This system offers a fair distribution process based on labor and value, beyond traditional airdrops.ğŸ“Œ ILO PhaseBetween March 24 and April 24, 2025, completing tasks spread over four weeks allowed me to get to know Autonomys Network better. Each week, I created content and talked about the project on X (Twitter), Reddit and blogs. By sharing this content with my followers, I made not only the project but also my own experience visible. Sharing a link to a sample piece of content and posting screenshots of the task submission pages on the platform gave the community a genuine and trustworthy impression. The fact that my two-week progress attracted attention in the community motivated me even more.ğŸ“Œ Flexible Vesting and Autonomys HubThe Flexible Vesting model offered by Autonomys Hub has shaped my motivation based on long-term contributions rather than short-term. Some of the tokens I earned were released immediately, while the rest were planned to be released over time. In the process, I not only completed my own tasks, but also contributed to the sustainable growth of the community by mentoring new social miners. Staying active in the vesting process allowed me to take ownership of the project and develop a professional perspective.

I'm glad to point you at a HUGE new release of BRINGUP-BENCH, a benchmark suite for CPU and accelerator development. This new release includes 20 MORE BENCHMARKS, plus significant improvements that now allow Bringup-Bench to run WITHOUT any I/O DEVICES, RUNTIME LIBRARIES, or OPERATING SYSTEMS. You can check out the new release here: https://lnkd.in/gfW889FsHere is what is in the new release (version 1.6):* 20 new benchmarks added, now for a total of 85 benchmarks!* TARGETs can now exclude benchmarks from their tests by adding them to TARGET_EXCLUDES in the Makefile* more benchmarks are now working on more targets* the SPIKE reference target now supports 8 MB memory* HASHALONE targets now are self-checking* the QSORT library implementation is now much more robust* an FP libmin_printf() problem was fixed, and it affected some benchmark outputs (which have been corrected)* the SPIKE and SIMPLE targets are now completely separatedâ€‹What is Bringup-bench? The Bringup-bench benchmark suite is a collection of 85 standalone C benchmarks designed to assist in the initial testing and validation of CPUs and accelerators. The suite is built to be easily hosted on simulated or real CPU platforms with no I/O devices, runtime libraries, or operating systems.â€‹ Running Bringup-bench, it is possible to perform deep functional testing of your design and early performance analysis. The benchmarks have modest runtimes; for example, running Bringup-bench on the IBEX RISC-V CPU RTL with Verilator, the entire benchmark suite completes execution in under 30 minutes.If you have found these benchmarks useful, please share your experience in the comments below. I see a lot of activity on the repo, so I would love to learn more about how Bringup-bench is being used.hashtag#computerarchitecture hashtag#hardware hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#CPU hashtag#RISCV hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#verification hashtag#validation

ğŸš€ Concurrency Battle: Java 21 Virtual Threads vs. Go GoroutinesConcurrency plays a crucial role in performance and scalability â€” and the way programming languages handle threads can make all the difference. Today, weâ€™re comparing two powerful approaches: Java 21â€™s Virtual Threads and Goâ€™s Goroutines.â˜• Java 21: The Rise of Virtual ThreadsJava 21 introduces Virtual Threads, a major step forward in simplifying concurrent programming.ğŸ”¹ Traditional Threading: Previously, Java required careful synchronization with synchronized blocks, ReentrantLock, and thread-safe collections like ConcurrentHashMap, leading to complex and error-prone code.ğŸ”¹ Virtual Threads: The JVM manages these lightweight threads, allowing developers to write straightforward, blocking-style code without worrying about the performance penalties of OS threads. In many cases, they dramatically reduce the need for explicit synchronization.ğŸ¿ Go: Built for ConcurrencyGo was designed with concurrency at its core. Its lightweight Goroutines and channel-based communication model make concurrent programming clean and powerful.ğŸ”¹ Goroutines: Cheap to spawn and managed by the Go runtime scheduler, they enable massive concurrency with minimal overhead.ğŸ”¹ Channels: Goâ€™s idiomatic way to coordinate goroutines â€” allowing communication to replace shared memory and locks in most cases.ğŸ— Key Differencesâ€¢ Synchronization: Java uses thread-safe constructs; Go favors communication via channels. â€¢ Complexity: Go is simpler out of the box. Java has improved significantly with Virtual Threads. â€¢ Runtime Management: Both models are managed by their respective runtimes, enabling lightweight concurrency. â€¢ Maturity: Goâ€™s model is well-established. Javaâ€™s Virtual Threads are newer but promising.âœ… In ConclusionJava 21â€™s Virtual Threads are a big leap, offering a concurrency model closer to Goâ€™s simplicity. While Go remains a go-to for clean concurrent code, Java developers now have modern tools to write scalable, readable, and efficient concurrent applications.ğŸ’¬ How have Virtual Threads or Goroutines shaped your projects? Letâ€™s discuss!hashtag#Java21 hashtag#Go hashtag#Concurrency hashtag#VirtualThreads hashtag#Goroutines hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#Threading

DAO Labs ILO Experience: Journey to a Contributively Just EcosystemIn the Web3 world, the number of fair systems where contributions are recognized is limited. However, the ILO (Initial Labor Offering) model developed by DAO Labs is set to change this perception forever. With both transparency and labor-based rewards, this model is not only a token distribution tool, but also a building block for sustainable community building. In this article, I will shed light on DAO Labs' ILO model with my personal experience.ğŸ“Œ Introduction to the Pledge PoolMy involvement as a social miner in DAO Labs' projects played an important role in my selection to the Autonomys Network ILO process. My interaction with the community, the quality of my content production and my previous contributions led to my inclusion in the Pledge Pool. Being included in this pool means that the amount of token allocation you receive will be directly determined by your work output. The higher the quality of the content you produce, the more reward you will receive. This system offers a fair distribution process based on labor and value, beyond traditional airdrops.ğŸ“Œ ILO PhaseBetween March 24 and April 24, 2025, completing tasks spread over four weeks allowed me to get to know Autonomys Network better. Each week, I created content and talked about the project on X (Twitter), Reddit and blogs. By sharing this content with my followers, I made not only the project but also my own experience visible. Sharing a link to a sample piece of content and posting screenshots of the task submission pages on the platform gave the community a genuine and trustworthy impression. The fact that my two-week progress attracted attention in the community motivated me even more.ğŸ“Œ Flexible Vesting and Autonomys HubThe Flexible Vesting model offered by Autonomys Hub has shaped my motivation based on long-term contributions rather than short-term. Some of the tokens I earned were released immediately, while the rest were planned to be released over time. In the process, I not only completed my own tasks, but also contributed to the sustainable growth of the community by mentoring new social miners. Staying active in the vesting process allowed me to take ownership of the project and develop a professional perspective.

I'm glad to point you at a HUGE new release of BRINGUP-BENCH, a benchmark suite for CPU and accelerator development. This new release includes 20 MORE BENCHMARKS, plus significant improvements that now allow Bringup-Bench to run WITHOUT any I/O DEVICES, RUNTIME LIBRARIES, or OPERATING SYSTEMS. You can check out the new release here: https://lnkd.in/gfW889FsHere is what is in the new release (version 1.6):* 20 new benchmarks added, now for a total of 85 benchmarks!* TARGETs can now exclude benchmarks from their tests by adding them to TARGET_EXCLUDES in the Makefile* more benchmarks are now working on more targets* the SPIKE reference target now supports 8 MB memory* HASHALONE targets now are self-checking* the QSORT library implementation is now much more robust* an FP libmin_printf() problem was fixed, and it affected some benchmark outputs (which have been corrected)* the SPIKE and SIMPLE targets are now completely separatedâ€‹What is Bringup-bench? The Bringup-bench benchmark suite is a collection of 85 standalone C benchmarks designed to assist in the initial testing and validation of CPUs and accelerators. The suite is built to be easily hosted on simulated or real CPU platforms with no I/O devices, runtime libraries, or operating systems.â€‹ Running Bringup-bench, it is possible to perform deep functional testing of your design and early performance analysis. The benchmarks have modest runtimes; for example, running Bringup-bench on the IBEX RISC-V CPU RTL with Verilator, the entire benchmark suite completes execution in under 30 minutes.If you have found these benchmarks useful, please share your experience in the comments below. I see a lot of activity on the repo, so I would love to learn more about how Bringup-bench is being used.hashtag#computerarchitecture hashtag#hardware hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#CPU hashtag#RISCV hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#verification hashtag#validation

ğŸš€ Concurrency Battle: Java 21 Virtual Threads vs. Go GoroutinesConcurrency plays a crucial role in performance and scalability â€” and the way programming languages handle threads can make all the difference. Today, weâ€™re comparing two powerful approaches: Java 21â€™s Virtual Threads and Goâ€™s Goroutines.â˜• Java 21: The Rise of Virtual ThreadsJava 21 introduces Virtual Threads, a major step forward in simplifying concurrent programming.ğŸ”¹ Traditional Threading: Previously, Java required careful synchronization with synchronized blocks, ReentrantLock, and thread-safe collections like ConcurrentHashMap, leading to complex and error-prone code.ğŸ”¹ Virtual Threads: The JVM manages these lightweight threads, allowing developers to write straightforward, blocking-style code without worrying about the performance penalties of OS threads. In many cases, they dramatically reduce the need for explicit synchronization.ğŸ¿ Go: Built for ConcurrencyGo was designed with concurrency at its core. Its lightweight Goroutines and channel-based communication model make concurrent programming clean and powerful.ğŸ”¹ Goroutines: Cheap to spawn and managed by the Go runtime scheduler, they enable massive concurrency with minimal overhead.ğŸ”¹ Channels: Goâ€™s idiomatic way to coordinate goroutines â€” allowing communication to replace shared memory and locks in most cases.ğŸ— Key Differencesâ€¢ Synchronization: Java uses thread-safe constructs; Go favors communication via channels. â€¢ Complexity: Go is simpler out of the box. Java has improved significantly with Virtual Threads. â€¢ Runtime Management: Both models are managed by their respective runtimes, enabling lightweight concurrency. â€¢ Maturity: Goâ€™s model is well-established. Javaâ€™s Virtual Threads are newer but promising.âœ… In ConclusionJava 21â€™s Virtual Threads are a big leap, offering a concurrency model closer to Goâ€™s simplicity. While Go remains a go-to for clean concurrent code, Java developers now have modern tools to write scalable, readable, and efficient concurrent applications.ğŸ’¬ How have Virtual Threads or Goroutines shaped your projects? DAO Labs ILO Experience: Journey to a Contributively Just EcosystemIn the Web3 world, the number of fair systems where contributions are recognized is limited. However, the ILO (Initial Labor Offering) model developed by DAO Labs is set to change this perception forever. With both transparency and labor-based rewards, this model is not only a token distribution tool, but also a building block for sustainable community building. In this article, I will shed light on DAO Labs' ILO model with my personal experience.ğŸ“Œ Introduction to the Pledge PoolMy involvement as a social miner in DAO Labs' projects played an important role in my selection to the Autonomys Network ILO process. My interaction with the community, the quality of my content production and my previous contributions led to my inclusion in the Pledge Pool. Being included in this pool means that the amount of token allocation you receive will be directly determined by your work output. The higher the quality of the content you produce, the more reward you will receive. This system offers a fair distribution process based on labor and value, beyond traditional airdrops.ğŸ“Œ ILO PhaseBetween March 24 and April 24, 2025, completing tasks spread over four weeks allowed me to get to know Autonomys Network better. Each week, I created content and talked about the project on X (Twitter), Reddit and blogs. By sharing this content with my followers, I made not only the project but also my own experience visible. Sharing a link to a sample piece of content and posting screenshots of the task submission pages on the platform gave the community a genuine and trustworthy impression. The fact that my two-week progress attracted attention in the community motivated me even more.ğŸ“Œ Flexible Vesting and Autonomys HubThe Flexible Vesting model offered by Autonomys Hub has shaped my motivation based on long-term contributions rather than short-term. Some of the tokens I earned were released immediately, while the rest were planned to be released over time. In the process, I not only completed my own tasks, but also contributed to the sustainable growth of the community by mentoring new social miners. Staying active in the vesting process allowed me to take ownership of the project and develop a professional perspective.

I'm glad to point you at a HUGE new release of BRINGUP-BENCH, a benchmark suite for CPU and accelerator development. This new release includes 20 MORE BENCHMARKS, plus significant improvements that now allow Bringup-Bench to run WITHOUT any I/O DEVICES, RUNTIME LIBRARIES, or OPERATING SYSTEMS. You can check out the new release here: https://lnkd.in/gfW889FsHere is what is in the new release (version 1.6):* 20 new benchmarks added, now for a total of 85 benchmarks!* TARGETs can now exclude benchmarks from their tests by adding them to TARGET_EXCLUDES in the Makefile* more benchmarks are now working on more targets* the SPIKE reference target now supports 8 MB memory* HASHALONE targets now are self-checking* the QSORT library implementation is now much more robust* an FP libmin_printf() problem was fixed, and it affected some benchmark outputs (which have been corrected)* the SPIKE and SIMPLE targets are now completely separatedâ€‹What is Bringup-bench? The Bringup-bench benchmark suite is a collection of 85 standalone C benchmarks designed to assist in the initial testing and validation of CPUs and accelerators. The suite is built to be easily hosted on simulated or real CPU platforms with no I/O devices, runtime libraries, or operating systems.â€‹ Running Bringup-bench, it is possible to perform deep functional testing of your design and early performance analysis. The benchmarks have modest runtimes; for example, running Bringup-bench on the IBEX RISC-V CPU RTL with Verilator, the entire benchmark suite completes execution in under 30 minutes.If you have found these benchmarks useful, please share your experience in the comments below. I see a lot of activity on the repo, so I would love to learn more about how Bringup-bench is being used.hashtag#computerarchitecture hashtag#hardware hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#CPU hashtag#RISCV hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#verification hashtag#validation

ğŸš€ Concurrency Battle: Java 21 Virtual Threads vs. Go GoroutinesConcurrency plays a crucial role in performance and scalability â€” and the way programming languages handle threads can make all the difference. Today, weâ€™re comparing two powerful approaches: Java 21â€™s Virtual Threads and Goâ€™s Goroutines.â˜• Java 21: The Rise of Virtual ThreadsJava 21 introduces Virtual Threads, a major step forward in simplifying concurrent programming.ğŸ”¹ Traditional Threading: Previously, Java required careful synchronization with synchronized blocks, ReentrantLock, and thread-safe collections like ConcurrentHashMap, leading to complex and error-prone code.ğŸ”¹ Virtual Threads: The JVM manages these lightweight threads, allowing developers to write straightforward, blocking-style code without worrying about the performance penalties of OS threads. In many cases, they dramatically reduce the need for explicit synchronization.ğŸ¿ Go: Built for ConcurrencyGo was designed with concurrency at its core. Its lightweight Goroutines and channel-based communication model make concurrent programming clean and powerful.ğŸ”¹ Goroutines: Cheap to spawn and managed by the Go runtime scheduler, they enable massive concurrency with minimal overhead.ğŸ”¹ Channels: Goâ€™s idiomatic way to coordinate goroutines â€” allowing communication to replace shared memory and locks in most cases.ğŸ— Key Differencesâ€¢ Synchronization: Java uses thread-safe constructs; Go favors communication via channels. â€¢ Complexity: Go is simpler out of the box. Java has improved significantly with Virtual Threads. â€¢ Runtime Management: Both models are managed by their respective runtimes, enabling lightweight concurrency. â€¢ Maturity: Goâ€™s model is well-established. Javaâ€™s Virtual Threads are newer but promising.âœ… In ConclusionJava 21â€™s Virtual Threads are a big leap, offering a concurrency model closer to Goâ€™s simplicity. While Go remains a go-to for clean concurrent code, Java developers now have modern tools to write scalable, readable, and efficient concurrent applications.ğŸ’¬ How have Virtual Threads or Goroutines shaped your projects? Letâ€™s discuss!hashtag#Java21 hashtag#Go hashtag#Concurrency hashtag#VirtualThreads hashtag#Goroutines hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#Threading

DAO Labs ILO Experience: Journey to a Contributively Just EcosystemIn the Web3 world, the number of fair systems where contributions are recognized is limited. However, the ILO (Initial Labor Offering) model developed by DAO Labs is set to change this perception forever. With both transparency and labor-based rewards, this model is not only a token distribution tool, but also a building block for sustainable community building. In this article, I will shed light on DAO Labs' ILO model with my personal experience.ğŸ“Œ Introduction to the Pledge PoolMy involvement as a social miner in DAO Labs' projects played an important role in my selection to the Autonomys Network ILO process. My interaction with the community, the quality of my content production and my previous contributions led to my inclusion in the Pledge Pool. Being included in this pool means that the amount of token allocation you receive will be directly determined by your work output. The higher the quality of the content you produce, the more reward you will receive. This system offers a fair distribution process based on labor and value, beyond traditional airdrops.ğŸ“Œ ILO PhaseBetween March 24 and April 24, 2025, completing tasks spread over four weeks allowed me to get to know Autonomys Network better. Each week, I created content and talked about the project on X (Twitter), Reddit and blogs. By sharing this content with my followers, I made not only the project but also my own experience visible. Sharing a link to a sample piece of content and posting screenshots of the task submission pages on the platform gave the community a genuine and trustworthy impression. The fact that my two-week progress attracted attention in the community motivated me even more.ğŸ“Œ Flexible Vesting and Autonomys HubThe Flexible Vesting model offered by Autonomys Hub has shaped my motivation based on long-term contributions rather than short-term. Some of the tokens I earned were released immediately, while the rest were planned to be released over time. I'm glad to point you at a HUGE new release of BRINGUP-BENCH, a benchmark suite for CPU and accelerator development. This new release includes 20 MORE BENCHMARKS, plus significant improvements that now allow Bringup-Bench to run WITHOUT any I/O DEVICES, RUNTIME LIBRARIES, or OPERATING SYSTEMS. You can check out the new release here: https://lnkd.in/gfW889FsHere is what is in the new release (version 1.6):* 20 new benchmarks added, now for a total of 85 benchmarks!* TARGETs can now exclude benchmarks from their tests by adding them to TARGET_EXCLUDES in the Makefile* more benchmarks are now working on more targets* the SPIKE reference target now supports 8 MB memory* HASHALONE targets now are self-checking* the QSORT library implementation is now much more robust* an FP libmin_printf() problem was fixed, and it affected some benchmark outputs (which have been corrected)* the SPIKE and SIMPLE targets are now completely separatedâ€‹What is Bringup-bench? The Bringup-bench benchmark suite is a collection of 85 standalone C benchmarks designed to assist in the initial testing and validation of CPUs and accelerators. The suite is built to be easily hosted on simulated or real CPU platforms with no I/O devices, runtime libraries, or operating systems.â€‹ Running Bringup-bench, it is possible to perform deep functional testing of your design and early performance analysis. The benchmarks have modest runtimes; for example, running Bringup-bench on the IBEX RISC-V CPU RTL with Verilator, the entire benchmark suite completes execution in under 30 minutes.If you have found these benchmarks useful, please share your experience in the comments below. I see a lot of activity on the repo, so I would love to learn more about how Bringup-bench is being used.hashtag#computerarchitecture hashtag#hardware hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#CPU hashtag#RISCV hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#verification hashtag#validation

Embchips IIoT Device Configuration hashtag#UI

Check out our newest hashtag#research in the Springer Nature International Journal on Software Tools for Technology Transfer (hashtag#STTT). We can now, fully automated, generate (learn) digital counterparts (state machines) of multiple communication protocols running on the same device using automata learning. The novelty is that we can really learn one single model at once, instead of generating one model for each protocol and trying to join them together. The rationale is that the protocols may influence each other (the whole is more than the sum of its parts) and therefore this should lead to more realistic models to analyze hashtag#security and hashtag#correctness - modern devices usually have more than one interface, after all. We show this on a Tesla key with both its BLE and NFC interfaces. Besides, we demonstrate a rigorous and comprehensive method for checking systems' compliance to a specification. This is a nice collaboration between AVL (including AVL DiTEST) and MÃ¤lardalen University in the AIDOaRt project.Co-authors:David SchÃ¶gler Marjan Sirjani Mikael SjÃ¶din The best thing: it's open access.

ğŸš€ Concurrency Battle: Java 21 Virtual Threads vs. Go GoroutinesConcurrency plays a crucial role in performance and scalability â€” and the way programming languages handle threads can make all the difference. Today, weâ€™re comparing two powerful approaches: Java 21â€™s Virtual Threads and Goâ€™s Goroutines.â˜• Java 21: The Rise of Virtual ThreadsJava 21 introduces Virtual Threads, a major step forward in simplifying concurrent programming.ğŸ”¹ Traditional Threading: Previously, Java required careful synchronization with synchronized blocks, ReentrantLock, and thread-safe collections like ConcurrentHashMap, leading to complex and error-prone code.ğŸ”¹ Virtual Threads: The JVM manages these lightweight threads, allowing developers to write straightforward, blocking-style code without worrying about the performance penalties of OS threads. In many cases, they dramatically reduce the need for explicit synchronization.ğŸ¿ Go: Built for ConcurrencyGo was designed with concurrency at its core. Its lightweight Goroutines and channel-based communication model make concurrent programming clean and powerful.ğŸ”¹ Goroutines: Cheap to spawn and managed by the Go runtime scheduler, they enable massive concurrency with minimal overhead.ğŸ”¹ Channels: Goâ€™s idiomatic way to coordinate goroutines â€” allowing communication to replace shared memory and locks in most cases.ğŸ— Key Differencesâ€¢ Synchronization: Java uses thread-safe constructs; Go favors communication via channels. â€¢ Complexity: Go is simpler out of the box. Java has improved significantly with Virtual Threads. â€¢ Runtime Management: Both models are managed by their respective runtimes, enabling lightweight concurrency. â€¢ Maturity: Goâ€™s model is well-established. Javaâ€™s Virtual Threads are newer but promising.âœ… In ConclusionJava 21â€™s Virtual Threads are a big leap, offering a concurrency model closer to Goâ€™s simplicity. While Go remains a go-to for clean concurrent code, Java developers now have modern tools to write scalable, readable, and efficient concurrent applications.ğŸ’¬ How have Virtual Threads or Goroutines shaped your projects? Letâ€™s discuss!hashtag#Java21 hashtag#Go hashtag#Concurrency hashtag#VirtualThreads hashtag#Goroutines hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#Threading

DAO Labs ILO Experience: Journey to a Contributively Just EcosystemIn the Web3 world, the number of fair systems where contributions are recognized is limited. However, the ILO (Initial Labor Offering) model developed by DAO Labs is set to change this perception forever. With both transparency and labor-based rewards, this model is not only a token distribution tool, but also a building block for sustainable community building. In this article, I will shed light on DAO Labs' ILO model with my personal experience.ğŸ“Œ Introduction to the Pledge PoolMy involvement as a social miner in DAO Labs' projects played an important role in my selection to the Autonomys Network ILO process. My interaction with the community, the quality of my content production and my previous contributions led to my inclusion in the Pledge Pool. Being included in this pool means that the amount of token allocation you receive will be directly determined by your work output. The higher the quality of the content you produce, the more reward you will receive. This system offers a fair distribution process based on labor and value, beyond traditional airdrops.ğŸ“Œ ILO PhaseBetween March 24 and April 24, 2025, completing tasks spread over four weeks allowed me to get to know Autonomys Network better. Each week, I created content and talked about the project on X (Twitter), Reddit and blogs. By sharing this content with my followers, I made not only the project but also my own experience visible. Sharing a link to a sample piece of content and posting screenshots of the task submission pages on the platform gave the community a genuine and trustworthy impression. The fact that my two-week progress attracted attention in the community motivated me even more.ğŸ“Œ Flexible Vesting and Autonomys HubThe Flexible Vesting model offered by Autonomys Hub has shaped my motivation based on long-term contributions rather than short-term. Some of the tokens I earned were released immediately, while the rest were planned to be released over time. In the process, I not only completed my own tasks, but also contributed to the sustainable growth of the community by mentoring new social miners. Staying active in the vesting process allowed me to take ownership of the project and develop a professional perspective.

I'm glad to point you at a HUGE new release of BRINGUP-BENCH, a benchmark suite for CPU and accelerator development. This new release includes 20 MORE BENCHMARKS, plus significant improvements that now allow Bringup-Bench to run WITHOUT any I/O DEVICES, RUNTIME LIBRARIES, or OPERATING SYSTEMS. You can check out the new release here: https://lnkd.in/gfW889FsHere is what is in the new release (version 1.6):* 20 new benchmarks added, now for a total of 85 benchmarks!* TARGETs can now exclude benchmarks from their tests by adding them to TARGET_EXCLUDES in the Makefile* more benchmarks are now working on more targets* the SPIKE reference target now supports 8 MB memory* HASHALONE targets now are self-checking* the QSORT library implementation is now much more robust* an FP libmin_printf() problem was fixed, and it affected some benchmark outputs (which have been corrected)* the SPIKE and SIMPLE targets are now completely separatedâ€‹What is Bringup-bench? The Bringup-bench benchmark suite is a collection of 85 standalone C benchmarks designed to assist in the initial testing and validation of CPUs and accelerators. The suite is built to be easily hosted on simulated or real CPU platforms with no I/O devices, runtime libraries, or operating systems.â€‹ Running Bringup-bench, it is possible to perform deep functional testing of your design and early performance analysis. The benchmarks have modest runtimes; for example, running Bringup-bench on the IBEX RISC-V CPU RTL with Verilator, the entire benchmark suite completes execution in under 30 minutes.If you have found these benchmarks useful, please share your experience in the comments below. I see a lot of activity on the repo, so I would love to learn more about how Bringup-bench is being used.hashtag#computerarchitecture hashtag#hardware hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#CPU hashtag#RISCV hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#verification hashtag#validation

Embchips IIoT Device Configuration hashtag#UI

Check out our newest hashtag#research in the Springer Nature International Journal on Software Tools for Technology Transfer (hashtag#STTT). We can now, fully automated, generate (learn) digital counterparts (state machines) of multiple communication protocols running on the same device using automata learning. The novelty is that we can really learn one single model at once, instead of generating one model for each protocol and trying to join them together. The rationale is that the protocols may influence each other (the whole is more than the sum of its parts) and therefore this should lead to more realistic models to analyze hashtag#security and hashtag#correctness - modern devices usually have more than one interface, after all. We show this on a Tesla key with both its BLE and NFC interfaces. Besides, we demonstrate a rigorous and comprehensive method for checking systems' compliance to a specification. This is a nice collaboration between AVL (including AVL DiTEST) and MÃ¤lardalen University in the AIDOaRt project.Co-authors:David SchÃ¶gler Marjan Sirjani Mikael SjÃ¶din The best thing: it's open access.

ğŸš€ Concurrency Battle: Java 21 Virtual Threads vs. Go GoroutinesConcurrency plays a crucial role in performance and scalability â€” and the way programming languages handle threads can make all the difference. Today, weâ€™re comparing two powerful approaches: Java 21â€™s Virtual Threads and Goâ€™s Goroutines.â˜• Java 21: The Rise of Virtual ThreadsJava 21 introduces Virtual Threads, a major step forward in simplifying concurrent programming.ğŸ”¹ Traditional Threading: Previously, Java required careful synchronization with synchronized blocks, ReentrantLock, and thread-safe collections like ConcurrentHashMap, leading to complex and error-prone code.ğŸ”¹ Virtual Threads: The JVM manages these lightweight threads, allowing developers to write straightforward, blocking-style code without worrying about the performance penalties of OS threads. In many cases, they dramatically reduce the need for explicit synchronization.ğŸ¿ Go: Built for ConcurrencyGo was designed with concurrency at its core. Its lightweight Goroutines and channel-based communication model make concurrent programming clean and powerful.ğŸ”¹ Goroutines: Cheap to spawn and managed by the Go runtime scheduler, they enable massive concurrency with minimal overhead.ğŸ”¹ Channels: Goâ€™s idiomatic way to coordinate goroutines â€” allowing communication to replace shared memory and locks in most cases.ğŸ— Key Differencesâ€¢ Synchronization: Java uses thread-safe constructs; Go favors communication via channels. â€¢ Complexity: Go is simpler out of the box. Java has improved significantly with Virtual Threads. â€¢ Runtime Management: Both models are managed by their respective runtimes, enabling lightweight concurrency. â€¢ Maturity: Goâ€™s model is well-established. Javaâ€™s Virtual Threads are newer but promising.âœ… In ConclusionJava 21â€™s Virtual Threads are a big leap, offering a concurrency model closer to Goâ€™s simplicity. While Go remains a go-to for clean concurrent code, Java developers now have modern tools to write scalable, readable, and efficient concurrent applications.ğŸ’¬ How have Virtual Threads or Goroutines shaped your projects? Letâ€™s discuss!hashtag#Java21 hashtag#Go hashtag#Concurrency hashtag#VirtualThreads hashtag#Goroutines hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#Threading

DAO Labs ILO Experience: Journey to a Contributively Just EcosystemIn the Web3 world, the number of fair systems where contributions are recognized is limited. However, the ILO (Initial Labor Offering) model developed by DAO Labs is set to change this perception forever. With both transparency and labor-based rewards, this model is not only a token distribution tool, but also a building block for sustainable community building. In this article, I will shed light on DAO Labs' ILO model with my personal experience.ğŸ“Œ Introduction to the Pledge PoolMy involvement as a social miner in DAO Labs' projects played an important role in my selection to the Autonomys Network ILO process. My interaction with the community, the quality of my content production and my previous contributions led to my inclusion in the Pledge Pool. Being included in this pool means that the amount of token allocation you receive will be directly determined by your work output. The higher the quality of the content you produce, the more reward you will receive. This system offers a fair distribution process based on labor and value, beyond traditional airdrops.ğŸ“Œ ILO PhaseBetween March 24 and April 24, 2025, completing tasks spread over four weeks allowed me to get to know Autonomys Network better. Each week, I created content and talked about the project on X (Twitter), Reddit and blogs. By sharing this content with my followers, I made not only the project but also my own experience visible. Sharing a link to a sample piece of content and posting screenshots of the task submission pages on the platform gave the community a genuine and trustworthy impression. The fact that my two-week progress attracted attention in the community motivated me even more.ğŸ“Œ Flexible Vesting and Autonomys HubThe Flexible Vesting model offered by Autonomys Hub has shaped my motivation based on long-term contributions rather than short-term. Some of the tokens I earned were released immediately, while the rest were planned to be released over time. In the process, I not only completed my own tasks, but also contributed to the sustainable growth of the community by mentoring new social miners. Staying active in the vesting process allowed me to take ownership of the project and develop a professional perspective.

I'm glad to point you at a HUGE new release of BRINGUP-BENCH, a benchmark suite for CPU and accelerator development. This new release includes 20 MORE BENCHMARKS, plus significant improvements that now allow Bringup-Bench to run WITHOUT any I/O DEVICES, RUNTIME LIBRARIES, or OPERATING SYSTEMS. You can check out the new release here: https://lnkd.in/gfW889FsHere is what is in the new release (version 1.6):* 20 new benchmarks added, now for a total of 85 benchmarks!* TARGETs can now exclude benchmarks from their tests by adding them to TARGET_EXCLUDES in the Makefile* more benchmarks are now working on more targets* the SPIKE reference target now supports 8 MB memory* HASHALONE targets now are self-checking* the QSORT library implementation is now much more robust* an FP libmin_printf() problem was fixed, and it affected some benchmark outputs (which have been corrected)* the SPIKE and SIMPLE targets are now completely separatedâ€‹What is Bringup-bench? The Bringup-bench benchmark suite is a collection of 85 standalone C benchmarks designed to assist in the initial testing and validation of CPUs and accelerators. The suite is built to be easily hosted on simulated or real CPU platforms with no I/O devices, runtime libraries, or operating systems.â€‹ Running Bringup-bench, it is possible to perform deep functional testing of your design and early performance analysis. The benchmarks have modest runtimes; for example, running Bringup-bench on the IBEX RISC-V CPU RTL with Verilator, the entire benchmark suite completes execution in under 30 minutes.If you have found these benchmarks useful, please share your experience in the comments below. I see a lot of activity on the repo, so I would love to learn more about how Bringup-bench is being used.hashtag#computerarchitecture hashtag#hardware hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#CPU hashtag#RISCV hashtag#benchmarking hashtag#verification hashtag#validation

Embchips IIoT Device Configuration hashtag#UI

Check out our newest hashtag#research in the Springer Nature International Journal on Software Tools for Technology Transfer (hashtag#STTT). We can now, fully automated, generate (learn) digital counterparts (state machines) of multiple communication protocols running on the same device using automata learning. The novelty is that we can really learn one single model at once, instead of generating one model for each protocol and trying to join them together. The rationale is that the protocols may influence each other (the whole is more than the sum of its parts) and therefore this should lead to more realistic models to analyze hashtag#security and hashtag#correctness - modern devices usually have more than one interface, after all. We show this on a Tesla key with both its BLE and NFC interfaces. Besides, we demonstrate a rigorous and comprehensive method for checking systems' compliance to a specification. This is a nice collaboration between AVL (including AVL DiTEST) and MÃ¤lardalen University in the AIDOaRt project.Co-authors:David SchÃ¶gler Marjan Sirjani Mikael SjÃ¶din The best thing: it's open access.

ğŸš€ Concurrency Battle: Java 21 Virtual Threads vs. Go GoroutinesConcurrency plays a crucial role in performance and scalability â€” and the way programming languages handle threads can make all the difference. Today, weâ€™re comparing two powerful approaches: Java 21â€™s Virtual Threads and Goâ€™s Goroutines.â˜• Java 21: The Rise of Virtual ThreadsJava 21 introduces Virtual Threads, a major step forward in simplifying concurrent programming.ğŸ”¹ Traditional Threading: Previously, Java required careful synchronization with synchronized blocks, ReentrantLock, and thread-safe collections like ConcurrentHashMap, leading to complex and error-prone code.ğŸ”¹ Virtual Threads: The JVM manages these lightweight threads, allowing developers to write straightforward, blocking-style code without worrying about the performance penalties of OS threads. In many cases, they dramatically reduce the need for explicit synchronization.ğŸ¿ Go: Built for ConcurrencyGo was designed with concurrency at its core. Its lightweight Goroutines and channel-based communication model make concurrent programming clean and powerful.ğŸ”¹ Goroutines: Cheap to spawn and managed by the Go runtime scheduler, they enable massive concurrency with minimal overhead.ğŸ”¹ Channels: Goâ€™s idiomatic way to coordinate goroutines â€” allowing communication to replace shared memory and locks in most cases.ğŸ— Key Differencesâ€¢ Synchronization: Java uses thread-safe constructs; Go favors communication via channels. â€¢ Complexity: Go is simpler out of the box. Java has improved significantly with Virtual Threads. â€¢ Runtime Management: Both models are managed by their respective runtimes, enabling lightweight concurrency. â€¢ Maturity: Goâ€™s model is well-established. Javaâ€™s Virtual Threads are newer but promising.âœ… In ConclusionJava 21â€™s Virtual Threads are a big leap, offering a concurrency model closer to Goâ€™s simplicity. While Go remains a go-to for clean concurrent code, Java developers now have modern tools to write scalable, readable, and efficient concurrent applications.ğŸ’¬ How have Virtual Threads or Goroutines shaped your projects?
